mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Navigating Systemic Barriers and Cultivating Seeds of Change
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Latina Preservice Teachers' Journeys into Stem Education

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Teachers of Color bring valuable assets into the classroom and play a vital role in empowering marginalized students (Brown, 2014; Dee, 2004), however these teachers remain severely underrepresented, especially in STEM fields (Irwin, 2022, 2023; NCES, 2020). Meanwhile, preservice teachers (PSTs) of Color often confront marginalization including lack of representation, isolation, and pressures to assimilate in teacher education programs situated in historically white institutions (HWIs) (Gist, 2017; Haddix, 2010; Hayes & Fasching-Varner, 2015). More specifically, Latina STEM PSTs encounter gender stereotypes, unwelcoming climates, and assumptions questioning their abilities (McGee, 2020; Ong et al., 2018). Understanding the barriers that these Latinas face, alongside their sources of resilience and resistance, can inform policies and curriculum to better support minoritized teacher candidates (Kohli, 2021). As such, the central question guiding this study asks: What are the experiences of three Latina STEM preservice teachers at a historically white institution (HWI)?Using frameworks of Latinidad, LatCrit theory (Sol贸rzano & Yosso, 2001), and transformational resistance (Sol贸rzano & Bernal, 2001), this study examines Latinas' intersectional barriers and resilience in white-dominated contexts of STEM and teacher education. Through two semi-structured interviews with each PST, aimed at eliciting their narratives on motivations and experiences in their program, I analyze using qualitative methods how these PSTs navigated systemic inequities and explore their resistance to systemic oppression (Hannegan-Martinez et al., 2022; Sol贸rzano & Yosso, 2001). Findings revealed four key patterns in Latina PSTs' journeys: (1) gendered and racialized microaggressions which affected their emotional and psychological wellbeing; (2) stark underrepresentation in STEM courses heightening isolation and self-doubt; (3) inspiration and motivation from personal experiences to pursue teaching of marginalized students, and (4) advocacy for engagement with sociopolitical issues affecting communities of Color within teacher preparation programs. Despite barriers imposed by dominant structures, the Latina PSTs displayed transformational resistance as they leveraged wisdom from lived experiences to inform their aspiration to teach (Yosso, 2005). Findings center the participants' knowledge and lived experiences to inform teacher preparation practices in ways that could better support other Latina PSTs in STEM. This study makes an important contribution by applying LatCrit frameworks to elucidate Latinas' diverse lived experiences at the intersection of race, gender, and class (Chavez-Moreno, 2023) and by positioning Latin* identities as assets for STEM teaching (Fierros & Delgado Bernal, 2016). Additionally, the study highlights the ongoing resilience and resistance of Latina STEM educators against layered oppression (Hannegan-Martinez et al., 2022). More broadly, the study underscores the urgent need for greater inclusiveness, representation, and cultural responsiveness in teacher education. This includes fostering spaces for minoritized PSTs to share their counterstories, openly discuss oppression, and nurture critical consciousness towards social justice (Kohli, 2021; McGee, 2021; Sol贸rzano & Yosso, 2002).
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Latinidad, Latinx, preservice teachers of color, STEM education, teacher education, teacher learning
Lama Jaber, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lara Perez-Felkner, University Representative; Sherry Southerland, Committee Member; Cameron Beatty, Committee Member.
